content.value: In a mesmerizing 56 seconds of the semifinals at the 2024 World Crokinole Championship, Connor Reinman and Jason Slater simultaneously secured perfect rounds.

value.figcaption: Double perfect round. Watch on YouTube.

content.value: Technically speaking, they each flicked a 3.2cm disc 30cm across a board into a 3.5cm hole (just 9% wider than the disc itself) eight times in a row. In game terms, they made eight open 20s each; a rare gem of Crokinole perfection on display when the stakes couldn’t be higher.
How did we get here? How rare is a perfect round? Is Reinman vs. Slater the modern day Magic vs. Bird? Was this one of those obscure new Olympic events? You may even be wondering, “wtf is Crokinole?”
If you find yourself sitting with any of these questions, then you’ve come to the right place.
A 20-second history

If you are from the southern region of the Canadian province of Ontario, you may already be well-versed in Crokinole due to its likely Canadian origin. But for the uninitiated, Crokinole is like a mashup of shuffleboard and curling, played on a tabletop board. It’s been around since the 19th century but has seen a steady rise in global popularity in recent years.

content.value: A 30-second game overview

Players take turns flicking discs toward the center, aiming to score high while knocking their opponent’s discs into lower zones or off the board. A shot must hit an opponent’s disc if one is present; otherwise, it must land in the inner circle (or score a 20 in the center hole). The round winner is whoever has the most points, and games consist of multiple rounds. Watch this video for a more thorough explanation of the rules.

content.value: Connor Reinman, the back-to-back world champion, and Justin Slater, the perennial powerhouse, are arguably the greatest players on the Crokinole world stage right now.
But how good are they? Let's start by looking at their open 20 skills, an indispensable part of success.

Reinman and Slater are two of the top competitors when it comes to open 20s, with success rates of 66% and 75%, respectively. In comparison, the average competitive player makes about 55% of open 20s during gameplay.

To put this in perspective for basketball fans, a competitive player making eight consecutive 20s in live-game action is like an NBA player making 20 straight free throws during the course of a game (or games). Not impossible, but definitely not common either.
But it’s just flicking a little disc across a small table. How hard can it be, right?

To put their skill in context, let’s compare it to a group of casual players, with experience ranging from a few to hundreds of games. Among these 10 players, success rates for open 20 shots during games ranged from 25% to 60%.

It's important to note that all of these percentages are based on in-game attempts, where a player’s rhythm for open 20 shots is interrupted by various other types of shots. In isolation, their skills can be even more impressive. Take Shawn Hagarty, for instance, who recently set an unofficial world record by making 64 consecutive open 20s.

value.figcaption: 64 straight open 20s by Shaw Hagarty. Watch on YouTube.

content.value: Now, back to the double perfect round. If we dive into the math, the odds of both players making eight consecutive shots can vary greatly depending on their skill level. Let’s explore the in-game success rates of different types of players to understand what we can expect.

content.value: Our theoretical scenarios provide a good sense of the odds for witnessing this phenomenon. Surprisingly, even a slight drop in skill has a significant impact. To catch a glimpse of this rare event, we really need both of the world’s top players hitting a hot streak simultaneously.

However, real games are far more nuanced and complex. Players — or their opponents — often miss early on. Here's what the data reveals after analyzing 300 rounds from various matchups in last season’s tournaments.

value.note: Based on 300 rounds from final to quarterfinal matches in the past year.

content.value: More often than not, the elusive double perfect round is lost right at the start. But I’ve been discussing this in the context of the most elegant form — a “pure” double perfect round, where all 16 shots are made as open 20s.

Technically, though, a miss doesn’t completely rule out a perfect round. A perfect round can (and often does) include a combination of open 20s and ricochet 20s, where a disc bounces in off the opponent’s. This introduces more complex and exciting gameplay scenarios, as going for a 20 isn’t always the best strategic move.
One thing is certain: more skilled players tend to keep the board clear and make open 20s at a higher rate, increasing the likelihood of a pure double perfect round when two top players face off.
And no, Crokinole isn’t an Olympic sport — yet.
